  }, {
    id: 80,

    category: "Digital Logic"
  }, {
    id: 81,
    question: "In a full adder, how many inputs are there?",

    difficulty: "Easy",
    category: "Digital Logic"
  }, {
    id: 82,
    question: "What is the purpose of a demultiplexer?",

    difficulty: "Medium",
    category: "Digital Logic"
  }, {

    difficulty: "Hard",
    category: "Digital Logic"
  }, {
    id: 84,
    question: "In a priority encoder, what happens when multiple inputs are active?",
    options: ["Error condition", "Highest priority input is encoded", "Lowest priority input is encoded", "All inputs are ignored"],
    correctAnswer: 1,
    explanation: "Priority encoder gives priority to higher-order inputs when multiple inputs are active simultaneously.",
    difficulty: "Medium",
    category: "Digital Logic"
  }, {
    id: 85,
    question: "What is the characteristic equation of a JK flip-flop?",
    options: ["Q(next) = JQ' + K'Q", "Q(next) = JQ + KQ'", "Q(next) = J + KQ", "Q(next) = J'Q + KQ'"],
    correctAnswer: 0,
    explanation: "JK flip-flop characteristic equation: Q(next) = JQ' + K'Q.",
    difficulty: "Hard",
    category: "Digital Logic"
  },
  // CPU Architecture (15 questions)
  {
    id: 86,
    question: "Which component fetches instructions from memory?",
    options: ["ALU", "Control Unit", "Registers", "Cache"],
    correctAnswer: 1,
    explanation: "The Control Unit fetches and decodes instructions from memory.",
    difficulty: "Easy",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 87,
    question: "What does the Program Counter (PC) register hold?",
    options: ["Current instruction", "Address of next instruction", "Previous instruction", "Accumulator value"],
    correctAnswer: 1,
    explanation: "Program Counter holds the memory address of the next instruction to be executed.",
    difficulty: "Medium",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 88,
    question: "Which CPU component performs arithmetic and logical operations?",
    options: ["Control Unit", "Registers", "ALU", "Memory Management Unit"],
    correctAnswer: 2,
    explanation: "ALU (Arithmetic Logic Unit) performs mathematical calculations and logical operations.",
    difficulty: "Easy",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 89,
    question: "What is pipelining in CPU architecture?",
    options: ["Executing multiple programs simultaneously", "Breaking instruction execution into stages", "Increasing clock speed", "Adding more cores"],
    correctAnswer: 1,
    explanation: "Pipelining divides instruction execution into multiple stages for parallel processing.",
    difficulty: "Hard",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 90,
    question: "RISC processors typically have:",
    options: ["Complex instruction set", "Variable instruction length", "Fixed instruction length", "Microcode control"],
    correctAnswer: 2,
    explanation: "RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer) uses fixed-length, simple instructions.",
    difficulty: "Medium",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 91,
    question: "Which register temporarily holds data being processed by the ALU?",
    options: ["Program Counter", "Stack Pointer", "Accumulator", "Instruction Register"],
    correctAnswer: 2,
    explanation: "The Accumulator register holds data during arithmetic and logical operations.",
    difficulty: "Medium",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 92,
    question: "What is the purpose of cache memory in CPU architecture?",
    options: ["Store permanent data", "Increase processing speed", "Handle input/output", "Execute programs"],
    correctAnswer: 1,
    explanation: "Cache memory provides faster access to frequently used data and instructions.",
    difficulty: "Medium",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 93,
    question: "In CPU architecture, what does 'fetch' phase involve?",
    options: ["Executing the instruction", "Decoding the instruction", "Retrieving the instruction from memory", "Storing results"],

    explanation: "The fetch phase retrieves the instruction from memory using the address in the Program Counter.",
    difficulty: "Medium",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 94,
    question: "What is the role of the Instruction Register (IR)?",
    options: ["Store the next instruction address", "Hold the current instruction being executed", "Manage program flow", "Perform arithmetic operations"],
    correctAnswer: 1,
    explanation: "Instruction Register holds the current instruction that is being decoded and executed.",
    difficulty: "Medium",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 95,
    question: "Superscalar processors can execute:",
    options: ["Multiple programs simultaneously", "Multiple instructions simultaneously", "Instructions faster", "Complex instructions"],
    correctAnswer: 1,
    explanation: "Superscalar processors can execute multiple instructions in parallel during the same clock cycle.",
    difficulty: "Hard",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 96,
    question: "Which architecture component handles interrupt requests?",
    options: ["ALU", "Control Unit", "Memory Management Unit", "Input/Output Controller"],
    correctAnswer: 1,
    explanation: "The Control Unit manages interrupt handling and control flow of the processor.",
    difficulty: "Medium",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 97,
    question: "In modern CPUs, what does 'out-of-order execution' refer to?",
    options: ["Random instruction execution", "Executing instructions before previous ones", "Reordering program sequence", "Executing ready instructions ahead of scheduled ones"],
    correctAnswer: 3,
    explanation: "Out-of-order execution executes instructions as soon as their operands are available, not in program order.",
    difficulty: "Hard",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 98,
    question: "What is the function of the Status Register (Flags Register)?",
    options: ["Store memory addresses", "Hold arithmetic results", "Contain processor status flags", "Manage instruction flow"],
    correctAnswer: 2,
    explanation: "Status Register contains flags that indicate the result of operations (zero, carry, overflow, etc.).",
    difficulty: "Medium",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 99,
    question: "Multi-core processors contain:",
    options: ["Multiple CPUs", "Multiple processing units on single chip", "Multiple instruction sets", "Multiple memory modules"],
    correctAnswer: 1,
    explanation: "Multi-core processors integrate multiple processing cores on a single chip.",
    difficulty: "Easy",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }, {
    id: 100,
    question: "Which component translates virtual addresses to physical addresses?",
    options: ["Cache controller", "Memory Management Unit", "Address bus", "Page table"],
    correctAnswer: 1,
    explanation: "Memory Management Unit (MMU) handles address translation between virtual and physical memory.",
    difficulty: "Hard",
    category: "CPU Architecture"
  }]
};

sourcesContent:
export const computerArchitectureQuiz = {
  topicId: 'computer-architecture-comprehensive',
  title: 'Computer Architecture Mastery Quiz',
  description: 'Comprehensive 100-question assessment covering all aspects of Computer Architecture',
  timeLimit: 7200, // 120 minutes
  questions: [
    // Number Systems (25 questions)
    {
      id: 1,
      question: "What is the base of the binary number system?",
      options: ["2", "8", "10", "16"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "Binary system uses base 2, containing only digits 0 and 1.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 2,
      question: "Convert binary 1011 to decimal:",
      options: ["10", "11", "12", "13"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "1×2³ + 0×2² + 1×2¹ + 1×2⁰ = 8 + 0 + 2 + 1 = 11",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 3,
      question: "What is the hexadecimal equivalent of decimal 255?",
      options: ["FF", "FE", "100", "AF"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "255 = 15×16¹ + 15×16⁰ = F×16¹ + F×16⁰ = FF",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 4,
      question: "In octal system, what decimal value does 742 represent?",
      options: ["482", "492", "502", "512"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "7×8² + 4×8¹ + 2×8⁰ = 7×64 + 4×8 + 2×1 = 448 + 32 + 2 = 482",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 5,
      question: "What is the 2's complement of binary 10110?",
      options: ["01001", "01010", "10110", "01110"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "First find 1's complement: 01001, then add 1: 01001 + 1 = 01010",
      difficulty: "Hard",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 6,
      question: "Which number system is most commonly used in digital computers?",
      options: ["Decimal", "Binary", "Octal", "Hexadecimal"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Binary is used because digital circuits operate with two states: ON/OFF or 1/0.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 7,
      question: "What is the range of signed 8-bit binary numbers in 2's complement?",
      options: ["-127 to +127", "-128 to +127", "-255 to +255", "-256 to +255"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "8-bit 2's complement ranges from -2⁷ to +(2⁷-1) = -128 to +127",
      difficulty: "Hard",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 8,
      question: "Convert hexadecimal 1A3 to binary:",
      options: ["000110100011", "00110100011", "110100011", "11010011"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "1=0001, A=1010, 3=0011, so 1A3 = 000110100011",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 9,
      question: "What is the BCD representation of decimal 47?",
      options: ["01000111", "100111", "0100111", "1000111"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "BCD represents each decimal digit with 4 bits: 4=0100, 7=0111, so 47 = 01000111",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 10,
      question: "In floating-point representation, what does the mantissa represent?",
      options: ["Sign of the number", "Magnitude of the number", "Position of decimal point", "Exponent value"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "The mantissa (significand) represents the significant digits of the number.",
      difficulty: "Hard",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 11,
      question: "Convert decimal 13 to binary:",
      options: ["1011", "1101", "1110", "1100"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "13 = 8 + 4 + 1 = 2³ + 2² + 2⁰ = 1101₂",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 12,
      question: "What is the octal equivalent of binary 110101?",
      options: ["65", "53", "64", "54"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "Group binary digits in sets of 3: 110 101 = 6 5 in octal",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 13,
      question: "What is the 1's complement of binary 10110?",
      options: ["01001", "01010", "10110", "01110"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "1's complement flips all bits: 10110 becomes 01001",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 14,
      question: "In which number system does the digit 'F' have a value of 15?",
      options: ["Binary", "Octal", "Decimal", "Hexadecimal"],
      correctAnswer: 3,
      explanation: "In hexadecimal system, A=10, B=11, C=12, D=13, E=14, F=15",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 15,
      question: "What is the decimal value of binary 11111111?",
      options: ["127", "255", "256", "511"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "11111111 = 2⁸ - 1 = 256 - 1 = 255",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 16,
      question: "Which representation can handle both positive and negative numbers?",
      options: ["Unsigned binary", "Signed magnitude", "BCD", "Gray code"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Signed magnitude uses the most significant bit to represent the sign of the number",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 17,
      question: "Convert octal 753 to decimal:",
      options: ["491", "483", "501", "475"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "7×8² + 5×8¹ + 3×8⁰ = 7×64 + 5×8 + 3×1 = 448 + 40 + 3 = 491",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 18,
      question: "What is the range of unsigned 8-bit binary numbers?",
      options: ["0 to 127", "0 to 255", "0 to 256", "-128 to +127"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "8-bit unsigned binary can represent 2⁸ = 256 values from 0 to 255",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 19,
      question: "In IEEE 754 single precision format, how many bits are allocated for the exponent?",
      options: ["8", "11", "23", "32"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "IEEE 754 single precision uses 1 bit for sign, 8 bits for exponent, and 23 bits for mantissa",
      difficulty: "Hard",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 20,
      question: "What is the Gray code equivalent of binary 1011?",
      options: ["1110", "1010", "1101", "1001"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "Gray code changes only one bit at a time: 1011 → 1110",
      difficulty: "Hard",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 21,
      question: "Which number system is base 16?",
      options: ["Binary", "Octal", "Decimal", "Hexadecimal"],
      correctAnswer: 3,
      explanation: "Hexadecimal system uses base 16 with digits 0-9 and A-F",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 22,
      question: "What is the result of binary addition 1011 + 1101?",
      options: ["11000", "10100", "11100", "10000"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "1011 + 1101 = 11000 (with carry)",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 23,
      question: "In two's complement, what decimal value does 10000000 represent?",
      options: ["-128", "-127", "128", "0"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "In 8-bit two's complement, 10000000 represents -128 (the minimum value)",
      difficulty: "Hard",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 24,
      question: "Convert decimal 200 to hexadecimal:",
      options: ["C8", "C0", "D8", "A8"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "200 = 12×16¹ + 8×16⁰ = C×16 + 8 = C8",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },
    {
      id: 25,
      question: "What is the purpose of parity bit?",
      options: ["Error detection", "Data compression", "Encryption", "Addressing"],
      correctAnswer: 0,
      explanation: "Parity bit is used for simple error detection in data transmission",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Number Systems"
    },

    // Computer Types (20 questions)
    {
      id: 26,
      question: "Which computer type is designed for single-user applications?",
      options: ["Supercomputer", "Mainframe", "Minicomputer", "Microcomputer"],
      correctAnswer: 3,
      explanation: "Microcomputers (personal computers) are designed for individual users.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 27,
      question: "What is the primary characteristic of a supercomputer?",
      options: ["Low cost", "High processing speed", "Small size", "Single user"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Supercomputers are characterized by extremely high processing speeds and computational power.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 28,
      question: "Which computer type is typically used for weather forecasting?",
      options: ["Microcomputer", "Minicomputer", "Mainframe", "Supercomputer"],
      correctAnswer: 3,
      explanation: "Weather forecasting requires massive computational power, making supercomputers ideal.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 29,
      question: "What distinguishes a mainframe from a minicomputer?",
      options: ["Processing power", "Cost", "Size", "All of the above"],
      correctAnswer: 3,
      explanation: "Mainframes have higher processing power, cost more, and are physically larger than minicomputers.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 30,
      question: "Embedded systems are typically which type of computer?",
      options: ["Supercomputer", "Mainframe", "Minicomputer", "Microcomputer"],
      correctAnswer: 3,
      explanation: "Embedded systems use microcontrollers/microcomputers integrated into other devices.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 31,
      question: "Which computer type can support thousands of users simultaneously?",
      options: ["Microcomputer", "Minicomputer", "Mainframe", "Workstation"],
      correctAnswer: 2,
      explanation: "Mainframes are designed to handle multiple users and large-scale processing simultaneously.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 32,
      question: "What is the typical use of a workstation?",
      options: ["Gaming", "Scientific computing", "Word processing", "Web browsing"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Workstations are high-performance computers designed for technical or scientific applications.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 33,
      question: "Server computers are primarily used for:",
      options: ["Personal use", "Providing services to other computers", "Gaming", "Educational purposes"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Servers provide services, data, and resources to other computers (clients) on a network.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 34,
      question: "Which computer type is most commonly found in homes?",
      options: ["Mainframe", "Minicomputer", "Microcomputer", "Supercomputer"],
      correctAnswer: 2,
      explanation: "Microcomputers (personal computers, laptops, tablets) are most common in households.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 35,
      question: "Cluster computing involves:",
      options: ["Single powerful computer", "Network of connected computers", "Mobile devices", "Specialized hardware"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Cluster computing uses multiple interconnected computers working together as a single system.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 36,
      question: "What is the primary advantage of grid computing?",
      options: ["Lower cost", "Resource sharing", "Better graphics", "Faster internet"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Grid computing allows sharing of computational resources and data across multiple locations.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 37,
      question: "Handheld computers belong to which category?",
      options: ["Supercomputers", "Mainframes", "Minicomputers", "Microcomputers"],
      correctAnswer: 3,
      explanation: "Handheld devices like smartphones and tablets are types of microcomputers.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 38,
      question: "Which computer type is designed for real-time processing?",
      options: ["Batch processing system", "Time-sharing system", "Real-time system", "Personal computer"],
      correctAnswer: 2,
      explanation: "Real-time systems process data immediately and respond within strict time constraints.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 39,
      question: "What does multiprocessing refer to?",
      options: ["Multiple programs", "Multiple processors", "Multiple users", "Multiple networks"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Multiprocessing involves using multiple processors to execute programs simultaneously.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 40,
      question: "Distributed computing systems are characterized by:",
      options: ["Centralized control", "Geographically dispersed components", "Single processor", "Local storage only"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Distributed systems have components located on different networked computers.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 41,
      question: "Which computer type is optimized for graphics processing?",
      options: ["Mainframe", "Workstation", "Graphics workstation", "Minicomputer"],
      correctAnswer: 2,
      explanation: "Graphics workstations are specialized for handling graphics-intensive applications.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 42,
      question: "Thin clients are typically used in:",
      options: ["Home computing", "Cloud computing environments", "Gaming", "Scientific research"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Thin clients depend on servers for processing and are common in cloud computing setups.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 43,
      question: "Mobile computing devices include:",
      options: ["Desktop computers", "Laptops and smartphones", "Mainframes", "Servers"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Mobile devices include laptops, tablets, smartphones, and other portable computing devices.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 44,
      question: "Edge computing refers to processing:",
      options: ["In the cloud", "Close to the data source", "In central servers", "In mainframes"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Edge computing processes data near its source to reduce latency and bandwidth usage.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },
    {
      id: 45,
      question: "Quantum computers are still primarily in:",
      options: ["Commercial use", "Research and development", "Home use", "Industrial applications"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Quantum computers are mainly in experimental and research phases, not yet widely commercialized.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Computer Types"
    },

    // Architecture Types (20 questions)
    {
      id: 46,
      question: "What is the main difference between Von Neumann and Harvard architecture?",
      options: ["Instruction set", "Memory organization", "Processing speed", "Cost"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Von Neumann uses shared memory for instructions and data, while Harvard uses separate memories.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Architecture Types"
    },
    {
      id: 47,
      question: "Which architecture suffers from the Von Neumann bottleneck?",
      options: ["Harvard only", "Von Neumann only", "Both architectures", "Neither architecture"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Von Neumann architecture has the bottleneck due to shared memory bus for instructions and data.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Architecture Types"
    },
    {
      id: 48,
      question: "In Harvard architecture, how many memory buses are typically present?",
      options: ["One", "Two", "Three", "Four"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Harvard architecture has separate buses for instruction memory and data memory.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Architecture Types"
    },
    {
      id: 49,
      question: "Which component stores both instructions and data in Von Neumann architecture?",
      options: ["CPU", "RAM", "ROM", "Cache"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "In Von Neumann architecture, RAM stores both program instructions and data.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Architecture Types"
    },
    {
      id: 50,
      question: "Modified Harvard architecture is commonly used in:",
      options: ["Mainframes", "Microcontrollers", "Supercomputers", "Minicomputers"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Many microcontrollers use modified Harvard architecture for better performance.",
      difficulty: "Hard",
      category: "Architecture Types"
    },
    {
      id: 51,
      question: "In Von Neumann architecture, what can cause the bottleneck?",
      options: ["Slow CPU", "Shared memory bus", "Large programs", "Multiple processors"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "The shared memory bus for both instructions and data creates contention, causing delays.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Architecture Types"
    },
    {
      id: 52,
      question: "Which architecture allows simultaneous access to instructions and data?",
      options: ["Von Neumann", "Harvard", "Both", "Neither"],
      correctAnswer: 1,
      explanation: "Harvard architecture's separate memory systems allow parallel access to instructions and data.",
      difficulty: "Medium",
      category: "Architecture Types"
    },
    {
      id: 53,
      question: "RISC processors typically use which architecture?",
      options: ["Pure Von Neumann", "Pure Harvard", "Modified Harvard", "None of the above"],
      correctAnswer: 2,
      explanation: "Most RISC processors use modified Harvard architecture with separate instruction and data caches.",
      difficulty: "Hard",
      category: "Architecture Types"
    },
    {
      id: 54,
      question: "In traditional Von Neumann architecture, where are programs stored?",
      options: ["CPU registers", "Separate memory", "Same memory as data", "Cache only"],
      correctAnswer: 2,
      explanation: "Von Neumann architecture stores programs and data in the same memory space.",
      difficulty: "Easy",
      category: "Architecture Types"
    },
    {
      id: 55,
      question: "Which architecture provides better security through memory separation?",
